title: Before 1 July 2019, will AT&T, Sprint, T-Mobile, or Verizon offer 5G smartphones to US customers?
preds: Made the mistake of binning AT&T as their release is only to their developer program members & business partners. Seems clear that their business partners will likely be included in the final assessment of this question though :| *sighs in defeat*

All the companies already released the 5G network to American Customers. The last one was T-Monile on June 28th. https://www.cnet.com/news/t-mobiles-5g-network-is-now-live-and-were-testing-its-real-world-speeds/

Per https://www.tomsguide.com/us/5g-phones-list,news-29292.html , T-Mobile is releasing June 28th, which will bring things to 4 if the scorers count the AT&T business-customer-only release.  Since that's how I expect them to score . . . (Alert to @Hammer-Time @runswithscissors @acohen )
July 1, 2019 is less than a week away presently.  It'd be more likely they'd offer it as a back to school or holiday item.
T-Mobile moved up it's launch date (I'm late to the party, I know). Adjusting to include them
Less than one week time for the announcement, no chance they will make it happen
AT&T, Sprint, and Verizon have all launched phones while T-Mobile is still saying second half of the year.
hat tip to @hammer-time, I looked again and sure enough T-,mobile is not offering phones yet.   https://www.pcmag.com/news/368886/race-to-5g-june-2019-update
Per @see and @bobrown, we may only be at 3 companies providing 5G phones... t-mobile outstanding...
T-Mobile plans for 5G appear to be in second half of 2019.

https://www.tomsguide.com/us/5g-phones-list,news-29292.html , updated today, doesn't mention T-Mobile.  So as best I can tell, we only have three.  Re: @Hammer-Time , my searches come up with AT&T for June 17, not T-Mobile.

Hat tip to @runswithscissors. Like them not sure this qualifies given developers not really customers (they are given phones at AT&T event June 22/23 as lead up to hackathon later in year). On business customer side, it sure sounds like question would be resolved as yes. So that gets us to four...

"Before 1 July 2019, will AT&T, Sprint, T-Mobile, or Verizon offer 5G smartphones to US customers? "
The wording seems to allow almost anything to qualify if it is sold to someone in the US by end of June.
Hat tip to runswithscissors. You just need one city with towers and handsets for sale to qualify as yes.

At&T will have for business customers, so I'm not sure if that counts, but I am going to say it does. 
https://www.neowin.net/news/att-launches-the-galaxy-s10-5g-but-consumers-cant-buy-it/
Sprint, Verizon and now T-Mobile (as of June 17). Not aware of a fourth in running - but possible I missed something.
3.5 weeks to go. Can’t get a lock on t-mobile release of s10. Sprint/Verizon already locked/loaded.
AT&T is taking longer than I expected.
AT&T still making no moves, Sprint & Verizon are locked, T-Mobile is looking more and more unlikely

Verizon Sprint are a lock. I pity the fool that isn’t 2 or higher.

LG V50 5G launching officially tomorrow on Sprint's network, S10 5G is out for Verizon, T-Mobile is a bit of a wildcard (I imagine they'd run the LG if the merger goes through?), but I think I misread AT&T substantially. They don't appear to be pushing for any phone release prior to the S10 5G & it's all but confirmed that they won't roll that out until Q3. Adjustment: [ ↔, 2↓, 10↑, ↔, 8↓ ]

Shifting lower since I can only find concrete plans with release dates for Verizon and Sprint. I assume the other two are working hard on launching 5G phones but I haven't seen release dates for from either.
Things are looking less certain than I thought for T-Mobile & AT&T. Still looks like they'll make it but not by much. Verizon is there, Sprint looks like a lock. Adjustment: [ ↔, 3↓, 3↑, 5↑, 5↓ ]
Time frame is too short to replace the most likely component supplier (Huawei).
Whether the offered service will work is still up in the air.

Sprint is about to take the plunge on its first speedy 5G-capable smartphone, announcing plans on the very day Verizon started selling Samsung's first 5G phone in the U.S. The No. 4 wireless carrier in the U.S. said on Thursday that the LG V50 ThinQ 5G will available May 31, initially to customers in Sprint's first four 5G markets – Atlanta, Dallas, Houston and Kansas City, Missouri. The availability date suggests that the end of May is when Sprint will flip on the switch in those 5G markets. Sprint also announced that the HTC 5G Hub for home broadband will also be available on that date.
https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2019/05/16/samsung-galaxy-s-10-5-g-verizon-goes-sale-sprint-5-g-coming-soon/3693470002/ 2 companies are locked in the question is the other two.

I’m going with ‘no.’ Basing a resolution in internet ads, and product design seems thin resolution in light of economic/political obstacle, yet to be enacted, prohibiting 5g .   Also internet ads (e.g Verizon) use future and conditional (wish) tenses rather than present tense. Again badly word q that should be voided...unless I’m right ;-)

Samsung is launching a phone on Verizon's 5G network May 16 (see article) while LG is launching a phone on Sprint in the first half of the year. It is possible AT&T or T-Mobile will have their own 5G phones but I haven't seen anything from them yet. https://www.tomsguide.com/us/5g-phones-list,news-29292.html

Details seem about as rare as rumors are plentiful right now, best I can tell the Galaxy S10 5G is pretty much a lock for launching ~ May16th & the OnePlus 7 is expected to launch right about the same time. That puts Verizon & T-Mobile in the lead from what I can tell. The LG V50 is supposedly set to launch next week as well. The really interesting bit will be the S10 5G's rollout to other carriers (all 4 around the end of June apparently. That makes things exceptionally difficult to forecast. I'll attempt to do so as follows Odds of OnePlus 7 launch w/ 5G on T-Mobile by July 1st: 90%
Odds of LG V50 launch w/ 5G via Sprint by the deadline: 75%
Odds of S10 5G launch w/ 5G on Verizon by the deadline: 99%...
    - on Sprint: 45%
    - on T-Mobile: 45%
    - on AT&T: 60% This gives...
Verizon: 99+%
T-Mobile: 95%
Sprint: 86%
AT&T: 60% Now comes the fun part where I forget how to plug in the numbers for 4 parallel non-dependent events... (Pretty sure it should skew more towards all 4, but gonna hedge this one a bit while I work on getting more details)

Based on the evidence from each cellular providers and the third parties analysis. The only available 5G-liked smartphone will release from Verizon on May 16 is the Samsung Galaxy S10 5G Flagship. 
AT&T, Spring, and T-Mobile currently working on the 5G network construction. There are 12 cities selected as the 5G technology test field by AT&T. Spring and T-Mobile are looking forward the full-scale 5G coverage in 2024, and the first 5G smartphone is the Moto Z3, which isn't 5G-capable but can be retrofitted with 5G connect with a 5G Moto Mod, and its expansion will not roll out until Dec 2019.

People are too wary of 5g and there are a lot of negative connotations. There needs to be a huge marketing spin and push on 5g to state it is necessary and the future. I have given 10% as one company may throw the dice and push it before all concerns are diminished. This company will be the weakest of the providers financially and will over exclusivity for a period of time possible 6-12months
AT&T is already trying to fake it with their 5Ge which is still 4G
Will they offer 5g phones - yes.  Will they have a nationwide network - absolutely not. All of them are already testing in limited markets,
5G will of course happen but doubtful before that date.
Infrastructure is not cheap and maybe not even perfected.  It would start in big cities.  Do the companies have the capital right now?

5G is about to get a big boost from Trump, but will it have an effect before the forecast horizon? Dateline 4-12-2019  -- https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/04/12/g-is-about-get-big-boost-trump-fcc/
expect verizon and tmobile to have 5g, verizon already announced a motorola phone

Will it work? Not very well.  Even 5G phones in South Korea are having problems.  But it is a big sell for the early adopters and a huge way to get free publicity.  There is a very high benefit to be first in the offer.  Verizon has already set May 16th as the date to offer it, and AT&T has pushed their date to Spring rather than summer to stay in the race

I think corporate bureaucracies will resist making the major investment required for as long as possible.  If one of the companies does, however, the other companies will follow as quickly as they can.
I dont think the investment in 4g has made enough of a return or the demand for 5g is significant enough for it to be rolled out this year
There are delays in 5g introduction because of the trade clash with China.
The infrastructure is not ready and the only chip that supports 2/3/4/5G is currently exclusive to Huawei. There's no point selling an unusable 5G phone.
It's too new for many to jump on the bandwagon but there is a chance of release.

This CNET article seems to be the most comprehensive and most recent source (April 5). [1] AT&T:
- They seem to have announced the Samsung Galaxy S10 5G for "later in the spring". [2] [3] Note that this phone will only be available at AT&T after being available through Verizon. [1]
"And AT&T announced it will carry additional Samsung 5G phones by the second half of 2019 (no word yet on the specific devices though)" [1]. This points toward a later release for any other Samsung phones.
- LG also seems make its devices available through AT&T only later in the year. [1] Sprint:
-  "The V50 will also be Sprint's first 5G phone" [1]
- The release date in Korea seems to be April 19 [6]. US release does not seem to have been announced yet. If the delay between the two is similar to Samsung (see below), a release around early June seems somewhat likely. Verizon:
- Verizon's first device will be the Samsung Galaxy S10 5G, which will first be available exclusively through Verizon. [1] In this article it says it will be available through other carriers "a few months later" [5]
- "Leaked render hints Verizon Galaxy S10 5G release for May 16". It's already been successfully released in Korea a few days ago. [4] [5] T-Mobile:
- On their website it merely says: "The first 5G phones will be available this year." [7]
- They seem to have delayed their full commercial 5G launch until the second half of the year due to technical differences to the other carriers. [8] Overall judgment:
- It seems very plausible to me that Verizon will launch the Samsung S10 before July 1. The leak seems fairly reliable from what I can tell, its already been released in another country, and Verizon has planned its 5G roll-out for April as well. I'd judge 90% that the phone will be launched before that date.
- The V50 is a bit harder to tell. They have already announced a release date fairly soon in Korea and Sprint has planned their 5G roll-out for May as well [8]. Overall, I'd judge there is a 70% probability they will also launch before the date.
- I think it's unlikely that Samsung or LG will make its phones available to AT&T or T-Mobile available before the date, based on the little that I've read on this. They don't seem to have other plans of their own. Even conditional on releases of the others before July 1, 6% for AT&T and 3% for T-Mobile seem adequate. There just isn't that much time. I'm not sure how to calculate the probabilities for 3 and 4 companies, so I'll just eyeball.
- 0: .1*.3=.03
- 1: .9*.3+.7*.1=.34
- 2: .9*.7=.63 [1] https://www.cnet.com/news/forget-att-fake-5ge-here-are-the-real-5g-phones-that-are-coming-galaxy-s10-5g-verizon-deployment-chicago/
[2] https://www.engadget.com/2019/04/09/att-5g-live-in-seven-more-cities/
[3] https://about.att.com/story/2019/mobile_5g.html
[4] https://www.sammobile.com/2019/04/08/render-verizon-galaxy-s10-5g-release-may-16/
[5] https://www.digitaltrends.com/android/samsung-galaxy-s10-5g-news/
[6] https://www.techradar.com/news/lgs-true-5g-ready-v50-thinq-has-a-release-date-and-price
[7] https://www.t-mobile.com/5g
[8] https://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/sprint-5g-rollout/

Sprint joining party in May

To forecast the availability of 5G smartphones to US customers, one needs to examine the status of the 5G networks first.  Without an adequate 5G network, 5G smartphones are not that useful.  LIfewire has a recent update on the status of the 5G networks in the US [1]. 
Note that the US companies have been focusing on delivering 5G internet access (in home and in companies) first with the mobile 5G network coming in later. In the US, Verizon’s 5G network is the most developed.  Its home/company network has been live in several cities since the end of 2018.  But its mobile network is being rolling out in April 2019 in only parts of Chicago and Minneapolis.  Two 5G phones, Samsung Galaxy S10 5G and LG V50 ThinQ 5G, will be available for launch in Verizon in 2019 [2].  Without a wide 5G network, it is hard to image that there is a rush to make 5G smartphones available.   On the other hand, the Galaxy S10 5G is going to be exclusive for Verizon at the beginning.  With two phones in the plan, I give a 70% chance for Verizon to have a 5G phone to sell by 30 June. ATT’s 5G E (for Evolution) network was launched in 2018, but it is not a real 5G network.  The real 5G network will roll out in the first half of 2019.  The same Galaxy and LG 5G phones are mentioned as available but the Galaxy is only available to ATT after the exclusivity period in Verizon (how ever long that is).  This, together with the less developed state of its 5G network, I give a 30% chance that a 5G phone being available for ATT customers by the end of the first half of 2019. Sprint will provide mobile 5G service to several cities starting in May.  Again the same two phones are mentioned to be available.  I give a 30% chance (same as ATT) that one will be available by 30 June. T-Mobile is, once again, dances to a different tune.  Unlike the other 3 networks, it is not rolling out 5G network bit by bit [3].  No 5G network is expected to be available until there is a national wide coverage.  As a result, no 5G smartphones will be available before then.    Take the probability of 70%, 30%, 30% and 0% for the available 5G smartphones for the 4 companies, the forecast for 
1 company only:    47%, 
2 companies only: 32%, 
3 companies only: 19%, 
4 companies:           0% and 
no company:            2%. 
(These values are computed conditional probabilities using a Venn diagram, such as described in [4]. [1] https://www.lifewire.com/5g-availability-us-4155914
[2] https://www.tomsguide.com/us/5g-phones-list,news-29292.html
[3] https://www.t-mobile.com/news/mwc-2018-5g
[4] https://www.ck12.org/probability/venn-diagrams/lesson/Probability-Using-a-Venn-Diagram-and-Conditional-Probability-ALG-II/

In first half of 2019, we should see major 5G network releases from both Verizon and Sprint. Following shortly thereafter we should see AT&T's 5G release in the second half of 2019 and then finally T-Mobile will roll out their 5G network in early 2020. 
https://www.whistleout.com/CellPhones/Guides/5g-mobile-carriers So only Verizon and Sprint by 1 July.

Verizon announced that their Samsung S10 5G would be available on April 5th. This will allow time for AT&T to begin selling the phone after Verizon's exclusive first rights end. Sprint is still planning to release their LG V50 ThinQ by the end of Q2 this year

Sprint could be first to roll out a real 5G smartphone service in the U.S. At MWC, Sprint made six 5G-related announcements including the commercial launch of its 5G service in May, starting in Chicago, Atlanta, Dallas and Kansas City with Houston, Los Angeles, New York City, Phoenix, and Washington D.C. also slated to launch in the first half of 2019. The Overland Park, Kansas-based mobile operator also announced the first 5G devices to be available this spring at the launch of its 5G service, the LG V50 ThinQ 5G smartphone, and the HTC 5G Hub which looks like a Google Home Hub or an Amazon Echo Show but acts as a Wi-Fi hotspot for up to 20 connected devices and can directly stream 4K videos to an external display. T-Mobile delays the launch of its unlimited 5G service On the other side of the spectrum (no pun intended),  T-Mobile confirmed at the show that it's delaying until the second half of 2019 the commercial launch of its 5G service—which mostly use the 600 MHz frequency band—because of the lack of a 5G smartphone that can operate on the 600MHz spectrum. At MWC, the New-York-based operator announced that LG's first 5G smartphone will also be coming to Verizon's 5G Ultra Wideband network this summer—a 5G network that is expected to cover more than 30 cities in the first half of 2019. So far, Verizon has confirmed three 5G devices that will be operating on its 5G network: The LG V50, the Samsung Galaxy S10 5G, and Motorola's Moto Z3 smartphone with the 5G moto mod case that is magnetically snapped on the back of the smartphone.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeanbaptiste/2019/03/10/mwc-2019-att-sprint-t-mobile-and-verizon-update-5g-plans/#7646bad95dd3 The Galaxy S10 5G isn't the only 5G phone coming. Here are all the others
https://www.cnet.com/news/the-galaxy-s10-5g-isnt-the-only-5g-phone-coming-here-are-the-others/ Basically T-Mobile is last and not going to launch by due date.
all 4 are offering the service and AT+T and Verizon should at least want to compete to have a phone, maybe a third.
Based on a recent Deloitte report that 72 operators tested 5G in 2018 and they expect 25 operators to launch 5G in 2019.

Sprint and Verizon have a high likelihood of release due to the Galaxy S10 and LG V50ThinQ. AT&T is advertising that their flagship 5G phone will be the S10, however, Verizon has exclusive rights to the device first and they are expecting a release at the end of the first half of the year, which means AT&T likely will not get to release the S10 until after Q2 of this year.
The Technology is there but the infrastructure is not yet ready.

Additionally, Sprint has plans to release an integrated 4G/5G phone by LG in the first half of 2019.  T-Mobile is using a lower band for 5G than the other three networks and thus will require a different phone model. There is rumor that Samsung will tweak the S10 to create a variant that works on T-Mobile's networks but haven't seen much proof yet. T-mobile's 5G roll out will likely take longer because they are focusing on wider coverage over higher speeds. https://www.pcmag.com/article/345387/what-is-5g

The device will sport a 6.7-inch display and six camera lenses, including two with depth-sensing time-of-flight sensors for improved augmented reality experiences. LG is releasing a 5G phone of its own, the LG V50 ThinQ 5G, and it will debut on Sprint's network.
    Sprint just announce a May launch for its 5G network in a handful of cities, while Verizon talked up its 5G service at CES 2019. AT&T is taking heat took heat for its 5G Evolution logo, which looks a lot like 5G, with speeds closer to 4G. T-Mobile is eyeing the second half of the year for its 5G push.

China's Xiaomi unveils $680 5G smartphone
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-telecoms-mobileworld-xiaomi/chinas-xiaomi-unveils-5g-smartphone-for-680-idUSKCN1QD0BC?il=0 Looks like 5G is coming.

5G is an incremental technology waiting for a killer application. 4G came so close to the physical limits of packing bits into bandwidth, information theory hard road blocks defined by the laws of physics, that there is little room left for 5G to offer real revolutionary advances. 
It's a smoke and mirrors technology put out by an industry that has not yet faced the fact that people lack the time to consume ever more data. There is only so much video in a month that someone can watch, and 4G does a pretty good job of doing it, and 5G is not the revolutionary jump that 3G to 4G was.
The killer app is not video for 5G because it doesn't carry much more data per HZ than 4G. 5Gs killer app is ultra low latency application. Which requires an ultra dense (expensive) network to work. Autonomous cars for instance. But AI, and pushing it to the edge, into the car, deflates the need for 5G low latency.
5G is about fast setup and tear down time of the comms link. Not congesting the signalling side of the network with slow session setup. Read IOT.... Read electricity metres and vending machines... Read penny's, not rivers of ARPU gold.
And so, while a great marketing event, the investors of Telco, the pension and Etf funds, are wary of allowing the engineers freedom to invest heavily in an industry where customers consumption has reached saturation, and future growth is in the machine comms, but AI in the machines means local autonomy in decision making, which means very low bandwidth, sending situation reports back to base, not... This is what I am seeing, tell me what to do before I collide with the car in front...data stream.
No indications that real 5g will be out that soon.

All of the carriers have announced they have, or will early this year, deployed 5G service in various cities. Samsung has announced their first 5G phone will be available in April and while I have not been able to find all the networks this phone will work on, it does suggest at least one or two will have a phone on their network. https://www.tomsguide.com/us/5g-release-date,review-5063.html

The first 5G phones are being demonstrated. Rival smartphone makers are expected to announce 5G models at next week’s Mobile World Congress, the industry’s top annual event, in Spain. Samsung said its 5G handset would be available in the early summer.

Sprint said last week that it plans to release 5G smartphones in the US with Samsung during the summer. Their plan is to include 9 US cities: Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Kansas City, Los Angeles, New York, Phoenix and Washington, DC. Verizon announced similar plans back in January saying they were planning to release 5G phones in first half of 2019. 5G can offer data speeds up to 50 or 100 times faster than current 4G networks. Apple said they are planning to wait until 2020 to release 5G iPhones (as reported by Bloomberg) Sprint sued AT&T late on Thursday, saying it is misleading consumers into believing that it is using fifth-generation wireless network, known as 5G, a technology that has not yet been widely deployed. AT&T customers are seeing a “5G E” logo on their mobile devices in over 400 markets. Although users are still using 4G network, AT&T is calling it 5G Evolution, a faster version of its existing network and a first step on the road to 5G. 5G can offer data speeds up to 50 or 100 times faster than 4G networks. The Samsung Galaxy S10 5G model could be the first mainstream device to run on 5G networks later this year (CNN).  Carriers are announcing "aggressive" launch dates but it's notable that, as it's been widely reported, full-scale coverage may be years away.  The technology needed for 5G requires "a higher-frequency band of the wireless spectrum called millimeter wave that allows data to be transferred much more rapidly than the lower-frequency band dedicated to 4G. But millimeter wave signals don't travel as far. This means that 5G networks will require many more, smaller antennas spaced closer together. 
Bottomline, 5G cellular waves needed for 5G do not travel as far as with 4G and 3G, and it will take time for carriers to build a sufficiently dense network of infrastructure. So what incentives do the companies have -other than competitive advantage- to offer these phones before they can be widely sold? 
Sprint is offering them in 9 cities.  
T-Mobile has just started promoting a new website to push their merger with Sprint announcing it will allow them to offer 5G as a cheaper and faster home Internet option compared to cable TV.  
So, it all seems to be moving fast and steady but we've been there with electric cars testing in NYC, charging stations etc.

With some companies looking at attempting mergers, it stands to reason that they would want to present a strong, innovation based public image. Phone companies constantly push for the perception of clout and ranking to lure the consumers into their grasp.

Difficult to find clear info on this - many articles basically the same (thanks Marketing departments). Expect better info around end of February. My numbers are basically semi-Informed guesses. Network info (in addition to links provided):

All four major carriers in the U.S. plan to have 5G available in at least some cities this year. And some phone makers plan to roll out devices in the first half of the year capable of taking advantage of 5G connectivity.Samsung has committed to release 5G phones in the first half of the year with two carriers — Verizon and AT&T. LG has already lined up a carrier to offer the manufacturer's first 5G phone. In LG's case, that's Sprint, which said last August that it would team up with LG to release a 5G handset during the first half of 2019.
https://www.tomsguide.com/us/5g-phones-list,news-29292.html Asked about 5G handset availability, Ray suggested that some T-Mobile 5G phones will be available in the first half of 2019,
https://venturebeat.com/2019/02/07/t-mobile-has-5g-towers-in-most-top-u-s-markets-handsets-arriving-in-2019/

I reckon they are all working on it. If any of Verizon, ATT, or T-Mobile announces, then the other two will. Sprint is probably too far behind and, in any case, will be hoping to be swallowed by T-Mobile.

I am a marginal no. I think Samsung may unveil its foldable phone 1st while regulatory issues continue to be worked out in the State and City levels on 5G deployment. .The slump or saturation of the Apple market invites them to try for market share but also warns them the consumer has what they think they need in hand all ready.
I believe if one of them begins to offer it, other companies will rapidly follow suit
